artist: Friedrich Ruysch; Joseph Mulder; after Joannem Wolters
creditline:
The Minnich Collection
The Ethel Morrison Van DerLip Fund, 1966
text: Ruysch invented a solution to preserve human organs and other organic material. He kept specimens in jars whose lids were topped with dioramas of natural—or natural-looking—objects, that often alluded to the contents. In the example illustrated in this etching, the dubious-looking coral branches on the top were actually hardened blood vessels, dyed coral-red. Despite their educational intent, these arrangements crossed the boundaries between science and showmanship.
title: Two jars, one with a hand , Tab. VII.  Fig. I, II.,  from "Thesaurus Animalium"
